case_name: Members of the first branch v. Damamma

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 910 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 910 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 28, 1961 of Mysore High Court in Regular Appeal No. M 70 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 28, 1961 ,of the Mysore High Court in Regular Appeal No.  M  70 of 1956.

facts.text: Registered deed dated September 4, 1900 executed by group of 19 persons forming joint family governed by Aliyasanthana Law.

anchor.surface_text: By a registered deed dated September 4, 1900, a group of 19 persons forming a joint family-with companymunity of property governed by the Aliyasanthana Law of inheritance,

facts.text: Deed divided family into two branches and divided properties.

anchor.surface_text: formed themselves into two branches and divided the family pro- 9 3 3 perties.

facts.text: Second branch consisted of descendants of Sarasamma and Brahmi and some descendants of Nemakka - 10 persons.

anchor.surface_text: The second branch companysisted of the descendants of Sarasamma and Brahmi and some descendants of Nemakka-in all I 0 persons.

facts.text: First branch consisted of Nemakka and rest of her descendants and her sister Sivadevi - 9 persons.

anchor.surface_text: The first branch companysisted of Nemakka and the rest of her descendants and her sister Sivadevi-in all 9 persons,

facts.text: In 1953, Damamma was sole surviving member of second branch, nissanthathi kavaru, 70 years old, no descendants.

anchor.surface_text: In 1953, Damamma was the sole surviving member of the second branch. She was a nissanthathi kavaru, 70 years old having numberdescendants.

facts.text: In 1953, members of first branch instituted suit against Damamma for partition alleging deed was for convenience of enjoyment and maintenance only, not absolute partition.

anchor.surface_text: In 1953, the members of the first branch instituted a suit against Damamma for partition of all the properties companyprised in the deed dated September 4, 1900, alleging that the deed effected a division for

facts.text: Defence of Damamma was that deed effected outright partition.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of Darnamma was that the deed effected an outright partition.

facts.text: Trial court accepted plaintiffs' contention and passed preliminary decree for partition.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt accepted the plaintiffs companytention and passed a preliminary decree for partition.

facts.text: Damamma filed appeal in Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Darnamma filed an appeal in the Mysore High Court.

facts.text: During pendency of appeal, Damamma died and Nagaveniamma substituted as legal representative under her will.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal she died and one Nagaveniamma claiming under her will was substituted in her place as her legal representative.

facts.text: Mysore High Court held deed effected outright partition, allowed appeal, set aside trial court decree, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the deed dated September 4, 1900, effected an out-right partition. On this finding, the High Court allowed the appeal, set aside the decree passed by the trial

facts.text: Present appeal filed under certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: From this decree the present appeal has been filed under a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Joint family properties formerly managed by yajaman Manjappa.

anchor.surface_text: The joint family properties were formerly managed by its yajaman, one Manjappa.

facts.text: Upon Manjappa's death, parties to deed apprehended disputes.

anchor.surface_text: Upon his death, the parties to the deed dated September 4, 1900, apprehended disputes.

facts.text: Object of deed was to prevent disputes, consequential wastage of property, preserve family dignity.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the deed was to prevent such disputes, and companysequential wastage of property and to preserve the dignity of the family.

facts.text: Deed provided that if no descendants completely in first branch, second branch entitled to its properties, and vice versa.

facts.text: In compromise dated August 10, 1909 in O.S. No. 10 of 1909, Damamma admitted deed was not partition but family arrangement for convenient enjoyment.

facts.text: Trial court found Damamma was major on September 4, 1900 but did not execute deed, described as minor under guardianship of Padmaraja.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt found that though Damamma, a member of the kutumba, was a major on September 4, 1900, she did number execute the deed. The deed described her as a minor under the guardianship of Padmaraja.

facts.text: Supreme Court held deed did not effect outright partition.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of the deed as a whole in all its parts, we are companystrained hold that the deed on its true companystruction did number effect an ,tit-right partition of the joint family.

facts.text: Supreme Court held deed not deemed partition under Section 366 of Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the deed dated September 4, 1900, on its true companystruction, did number effect an out-right partition number can it be deemed to be a deed of partition under S. 36 6  of the Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949.

facts.text: Appeal allowed without costs, High Court judgment set aside, trial court decree restored.

anchor.surface_text: In -the result, the appeal is allowed without companyts, the judgment and decree passed by the High Court is sell aside, and the decree of the trial companyrt is restored.

facts.text: Deed restrained members from alienating properties or incurring debts binding on family properties.

anchor.surface_text: The members of the two branches were restrained from incurring debts binding on the family properties and from alienating the properties or any portion thereof and granting any leases except in the ordinary companyrse of management.

issues.text: whether the deed dated September 4, 1900, effected a disruption of the joint family or whether it made a division for companyvenience of enjoyment and maintenance only

anchor.surface_text: The sole question arising in this appeal is whether the deed dated September 4, 1900, effected a disruption of the joint family or whether it made a division for companyvenience of enjoyment and maintenance only.

issues.text: whether the deed should be deemed to have effected a partition of the joint family properties under section 36 6  of the Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent contended that the deed should be deemed to have effected a partition of the joint family pro- perties under section 36 6  of the Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949.

arguments.claim: features of deed indicate outright partition: divided shares, perpetual separate enjoyment, separate mutations/pattas/assessments/managers/debts

anchor.surface_text: The respondent relies on several features of the deed as indicative of an out-right partition. The properties were divided into two shares. Each branch was to enjoy its share in perpetuity from generation to generation without any interference from the other branch. There would be separate mutations and separate pattas

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sole surviving kavaru would be entitled to dispose- of her separate property by a will under the provisions of the Malabar Wills Act 898. The absence

arguments.court_reasoning: counter-features like object, no disruption declaration, artificial branches, restrictions, survivorship outweigh

arguments.claim: object of deed to prevent disputes/wastage/preserve dignity and no declaration of complete disruption indicate not partition

anchor.surface_text: But there are other features of the deed which indicate that it did not effect an out-right partition. The object of the deed was to prevent disputes and wastage of properties and to preserve the dignity of the family. In terms, the deed did not declare

arguments.claim: deed splits kutumba into artificial branches not natural kavarus, unlike usual partition

anchor.surface_text: In case of a partition, a Kutumba governed by the Aliyasanthana law is usually split up according to natural kavarus but under this deed, the Kutumba was split up into two artificial branches.

arguments.claim: restrictions on debts/alienation to preserve family properties for both branches indicate no outright partition; HC's S.10 TPA ruling assumes issue

anchor.surface_text: The members of the two branches were restrained from incurring debts binding on the family properties and from alienating the properties or any portion thereof and granting any leases except in the ordinary course of management. These restrictions were obviously placed for the purpose of preserving the family properties intact for the benefit of both branches. The High Court said that as the deed effected an out-right partition, the conditions restraining alienations were void under Sec. 10 of the Transfer of Property Act.

arguments.claim: survivorship clause for nissanthathi kavaru properties passing to other branch indicates retained community/survivorship

anchor.surface_text: On the nissanthathi, its properties would pass to the members of the other branch. This clause indicates that on one branch becoming extinct, the properties allotted to it would pass by survivorship of the other branch.

arguments.claim: absence of right to dispose by will (available post-partition under Malabar Wills Act) indicates no complete disruption

anchor.surface_text: Had there been an out-right partition, the sole surviving kavaru would be entitled to dispose of her separate property by a will under the provisions of the Malabar Wills Act 1898. The absence of such a right indicates that the deed did not effect a complete disruption

arguments.claim: Damamma admitted in 1909 compromise that deed was family arrangement for convenient enjoyment, not partition

anchor.surface_text: We may add that in a compromise dated August 10, 1909 in O.S. No. 10 of 1909 ... which the members of the second branch were parties, Damamma solemnly admitted and declared that the deed was not a partition deed, but was a family arrangement

arguments.claim: on true construction, deed did not effect outright partition

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of the deed as a whole in all its parts, we are constrained hold that the deed on its true construction did not effect an ,out-right partition of the joint family.

arguments.claim: deed deemed partition under S.366 Madras Aliyasantana Act

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondent contended that the deed should be deemed to have effected a partition of the joint family properties under section 366 of the Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949.

arguments.claim: S.366 requires 4 conditions, deed fails them

anchor.surface_text: As was pointed out by Ramaswami J. in Kaveri v. Ganga Ratna, the following four conditions are the necessary prerequisites for the application of Sec. 366: 1 there is a registered family settlement...

holdings.text: The deed dated September 4, 1900 on its true construction did not effect an outright partition of the joint family.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of the deed as a whole in all its parts, we are companystrained hold that the deed on its true companystruction did number effect an ,tit-right partition of the joint family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deed considered as a whole shows family arrangement not partition: object to prevent disputes without declaring disruption, artificial branches unlike natural kavarus, restrictions on alienation/debts to preserve properties for both branches, survivorship on extinction, no right to will property, prior admission by Damamma.

holdings.text: The deed dated September 4, 1900 cannot be deemed a deed of partition under Section 366 of the Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the deed dated September 4, 1900, on its true companystruction, did number effect an out-right partition number can it be deemed to be a deed of partition under S. 36 6  of the Madras Aliyasantana Act, 1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fails four prerequisites from Kaveri v. Ganga Ratna: Damamma major but did not execute deed; unclear if all kutumba properties distributed; distribution among artificial branches not natural kavarus per S.3(b); S.366 requires split according to defined kavarus.

holdings.text: Section 366 of the Madras Aliyasantana Act applies only to family settlements splitting kutumba according to natural kavarus defined in S.3(b).

anchor.surface_text: S. 3 b  defines kavaru. Used in relation to a female, it means the group of persons companysisting of that female, her children and all her descendants in the female line, and used in relation to a male, it means the kavaru of the mother of that male. Having regard to the scheme of S. 36, we think that S. 36 6  applies to a family settlement under which the kutumba is split up according to kavarus as defined in S. 3 b  and the kutumba properties are distributed among such kavarus.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of S.36 and definition in S.3(b) limit S.366 to distributions among natural lineage groups (kavarus), not artificial groups created by deed.

holdings.text: Restrictions on alienation in the deed are not hit by Section 10 of the Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: If the family arrangement took effect as a division for companyvenience of enjoyment only, and number as an out-right partition, the restrictions on alienations were number hit by Sec. 10 of the Transfer of Property

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restrictions valid under family arrangement for convenience as they preserve properties for branches; S.10 applies only post outright partition, which did not occur.

anchor.surface_text: S. 3 b  defines kavaru. Used in relation to a female, it means the group of persons companysisting of that female, her children and all her descendants in the female line, and used in relation to a male, it means the kavaru of the mother of that male. Having regard to the scheme of S. 36, we think that S. 36 6  applies to a family settlement under which the kutumba is split up according to kavarus as defined in S. 3 b  and the kutumba properties are distributed among such kavarus.
